actions-list.actionItem: The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 167.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Westerman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 167 — "To amend the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 to authorize partnerships between States and nongovernmental entities for the purpose of reclaiming and restoring land and water resources adversely affected by coal mining activities before August 3, 1977, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 331.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Westerman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 331 — "To amend the Aquifer Recharge Flexibility Act to clarify a provision relating to conveyances for aquifer recharge purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1612.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Westerman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 1612 — "To designate the Flatside-Bethune Wilderness in the Ouachita National Forest, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1682.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Westerman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 1682 — "To amend the Federal Lands Recreation Enhancement Act to provide for lifetime National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Passes for family members of members of the Armed Forces who lost their lives while serving their country."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H. Con. Res. 30.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Jordan moved to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution. H. Con. Res. 30 — "Expressing support for local law enforcement officers."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H. Res. 364.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Onder moved to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution. H. Res. 364 — "Calling upon local communities to support organizations that provide resources and aid Gold Shield Families in their time of need."
The Speaker announced that votes on suspensions, if ordered, will be postponed until a time to be announced.

actions-list.header: United States-China Economic and Security Review Commission
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to section 1238(b)(3) of the Floyd D. Spence National Defense Authorization Act for fiscal year 2001 (22 U.S.C. 7002), as amended, and the order of the House of January 3, 2025, the Speaker appointed Mr. Joshua Hodges, Batavia, Illinois, for a term expiring on December 31, 2026.

actions-list.header: Board of Trustees of the Harry S. Truman Scholarship Foundation
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to 20 U.S.C. 2004(b), and the order of the House of January 3, 2025, the Speaker appointed the following member of the House to the Board of Trustees of the Harry S. Truman Scholarship Foundation: Mr. Amo.

Pursuant to 36 U.S.C. 2302, and the order of the House of January 3, 2025, the Speaker appointed the following members of the House to the United States Holocaust Memorial Council: Mr. Schneider and Ms. Lois Frankel of Florida.

actions-list.header: Governing Board of the Office of Congressional Conduct
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to section 4(d) of House Resolution 5, 119th Congress, and the order of the House of January 3, 2025, the Speaker appointed Ms. Karen L. Haas, Maryland, Chair, and Mr. Leon A. Westmoreland, Georgia, and the Minority Leader appointed Mr. William P. Luther, Minnesota, Co-Chair, and Ms. Lorraine C. Miller, Texas.
The House resumed with one minute speeches.

actions-list.header: NOTIFICATION OF INTENT TO OFFER RESOLUTION
actions-list.actionItem: Mr. Thanedar notified the House of his intent to offer a privileged resolution pursuant to clause 2(a)(1) of rule IX. The Chair announced that a determination will be made at the time designated for consideration of the resolution.
The House proceeded with one minute speeches.
The Chair designated Ms. Craig to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of May 13.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 2:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 2:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Mariannette Miller-Meeks to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
